plants.name: Chrysanthemum
plants.description: Chrysanthemums are popular garden flowers known for their vibrant, pompom-shaped blooms, often symbolizing autumn in temperate regions. They come in a variety of colors and are widely cultivated for fall displays.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide (Asia, Europe, North America)
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums have been cultivated in China for over 2,500 years and are considered a symbol of longevity and rejuvenation.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: Camellia japonica is an evergreen shrub that blooms in late fall to early spring with rose-like flowers, often in shades of pink, red, or white. It thrives in mild, temperate climates, especially in parts of East Asia and the southeastern United States.
plants.location: East Asia and mild temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: The Camellia flower is the state flower of Alabama, USA, and has significant cultural value in East Asia.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: Grevillea robusta is a fast-growing Australian native tree with bright orange, spider-like flowers. It often blooms in spring and autumn in subtropical and tropical climates, providing nectar for birds and insects.
plants.bloomingSeason: October to November, and sometimes throughout the year
plants.funFact: Despite its name 'Robusta,' the Silky Oak is not an oak but belongs to the protea family.

plants.name: Calendula officinalis
plants.description: Calendula is a hardy annual plant with bright orange or yellow daisy-like flowers. It blooms profusely in cooler months of fall and early winter in temperate regions and is often grown in herb gardens.
plants.funFact: Calendula flowers have been used medicinally and as a natural dye since ancient times.
